questions.text: Patient was started on HAART. What is used to monitor efficacy of treatment?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Viral load refers to the amount of HIV RNA in the blood. A declining or undetectable viral load indicates that the therapy is effective in suppressing viral replication.
  • • Regular monitoring helps assess:
  • • Response to therapy
  • • Adherence to treatment
  • • Development of resistance
  • • Why not the other options? B. P24 antigen: Useful for early diagnosis of HIV before antibodies develop but not for ongoing treatment monitoring.
  • • C. HIV-1 antibody: Once positive, it typically remains positive for life, regardless of treatment success.
  • • D. Viral serotype: Not used to monitor treatment; it refers to identifying the type/subtype of HIV.

questions.text: A patient visited Africa and died of a disease. Autopsy showed intra nuclear Torres bodies. Which vaccine strain could have prevented this disease?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Clue in the question: Visited Africa → Endemic area for Yellow Fever.
  • • Died of a disease with intranuclear Torres bodies → Torres bodies are eosinophilic inclusions seen in hepatocytes infected by Yellow Fever virus.
  • • This points to Yellow Fever, which is vaccine-preventable with the 17D strain.
  • • Why not the others? A. SA 14-14-2 → Vaccine for Japanese Encephalitis.
  • • C. Nakayama → Another Japanese Encephalitis vaccine strain.
  • • D. Jeryl-Lynn → Mumps vaccine strain (part of MMR).

questions.text: A truck driver admitted with cough and breathlessness. HPE revealed septate hyphae with 45deg angle branching as shown in the image. Identify the correct pathogen.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Septate hyphae with acute angle (≈45°) branching
  • • This is characteristic of Aspergillus species, a filamentous fungus that commonly causes pulmonary aspergillosis, especially in people with underlying lung disease or immunosuppression.
  • • How to differentiate fungal pathogens based on morphology: Fungal Pathogen Hyphae Characteristics Branching Angle Septation Aspergillus Thin, uniform, acute angle branching ~45° Septate Mucor/Rhizopus Broad, ribbon-like, irregular branching ~90° Non-septate or sparsely septate Absidia Similar to Mucor/Rhizopus (Zygomycetes group) ~90° Non-septate

questions.text: A HIV positive person developed fever, Cough, lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. The infectious agent was in yeast form at 370 C and mold form at 220C. Produces red color pigment in the culture. Microscopy shown in the image. What is the diagnosis ?
A farmer came with cauliflower like growth in foot. Biopsy shown copper penny or sclerotic bodies. Choose the correct diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue caused by pigmented (dematiaceous) fungi such as Fonsecaea, Phialophora, and Cladophialophora species.
  • • The sclerotic bodies (also known as Medlar bodies, copper penny bodies, or muriform cells) are characteristic histopathological findings in chromoblastomycosis.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Sporotrichosis – Usually presents with nodular lesions along lymphatics (sporotrichoid spread), not cauliflower-like growth, and does not show copper penny bodies.
  • • C. Mycetoma – Can also affect the foot and form granules, but shows grains or granules of fungi or bacteria, not sclerotic bodies.
  • • D. Cutaneous blastomycosis – Caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis and presents with verrucous lesions, but does not show copper penny bodies on histology.

questions.text: A patient presented with curdy white vaginal discharge. Choose the correct medium used to identify the species of this pathogen?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • To identify and differentiate Candida species, the preferred medium is Candida Chrom agar.
  • • Candida Chrom agar: It is a selective and differential medium.
  • • Different Candida species produce distinctive colored colonies, aiding in rapid identification:
  • • Candida albicans – green
  • • Candida tropicalis – blue to purple
  • • Candida krusei – pink, fuzzy
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. SDA (Sabouraud Dextrose Agar) – Good for general fungal growth but does not differentiate species.
  • • B. Bird seed agar (Niger seed agar) – Used specifically for Cryptococcus neoformans, which produces brown colonies.
  • • D. Cornmeal agar – Used for morphological studies (e.g., formation of pseudohyphae, chlamydospores), not ideal for rapid species identification.

questions.text: A wrestler presented with itch in axilla. The organism produced velvety colonies with underside red colour pigment in culture . Microscopy shown pencil shaped macroconidia and abundant microconidia . Diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Clinical presentation:
  • • Wrestler with itch in the axilla → common site for tinea corporis or tinea cruris.
  • • Wrestlers are at higher risk due to close skin contact ("tinea corporis gladiatorum").
  • • Culture characteristics:
  • • Velvety colonies with a red pigment on the reverse (underside) are classic for T. rubrum.
  • • Microscopy:
  • • Shows pencil-shaped macroconidia.
  • • Abundant microconidia, typically teardrop or peg-shaped, along hyphae.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. T. mentagrophytes: Has more granular colonies and no red pigment on the reverse; shows spiral hyphae and grape-like clusters of microconidia.
  • • C. T. schoenleinii: Causes favus, forms favic chandeliers (antler-like hyphae); rare in this context.
  • • D. T. tonsurans: More commonly causes tinea capitis; produces variable microconidia and few macroconidia, not pencil-shaped.

questions.text: A 28 year old lady admitted with fever, nausea and anorexia for 2 months duration.HbsAg positive, anti HBc IgM positive. Anti HCV negative. Whats is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Symptoms: Fever, nausea, anorexia for 2 months — consistent with acute hepatitis.
  • • HBsAg positive: Indicates active hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection.
  • • Anti-HBc IgM positive: This is the most specific marker of acute hepatitis B infection.
  • • Anti-HCV negative: Rules out hepatitis C.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Acute hepatitis C – Ruled out because anti-HCV is negative.
  • • B. Chronic hepatitis C – Also ruled out by anti-HCV negativity.
  • • D. Chronic hepatitis B – Would show HBsAg positive and anti-HBc IgG, not IgM.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy came to emergency department with c/o fever for a week, tender hepatomegaly, jaundice, calf pain, mild sore throat and conjunctival suffusion. No c/o vomiting, cough and hemorrhage. Urine output normal. No travel history. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Key Clinical Clues: Fever lasting a week
  • • Tender hepatomegaly and jaundice – suggests hepatic involvement
  • • Calf pain – a classic symptom in leptospirosis
  • • Mild sore throat and conjunctival suffusion – highly characteristic of leptospirosis
  • • Normal urine output – indicates no severe renal impairment yet
  • • No hemorrhage or travel history – less likely to be dengue or a tropical viral illness
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Chikungunya – More likely to cause rash and severe joint pains; hepatomegaly and conjunctival suffusion are not typical.
  • • C. Hepatitis A – Can cause fever and jaundice but does not typically cause calf pain or conjunctival suffusion.
  • • D. Dengue hemorrhagic fever – Would usually present with bleeding manifestations, low platelet count, and signs of plasma leakage, which are absent here.

questions.text: What is false about pseudo membrane colitis/ C. difficle?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment

options.label: D
options.text: Pseudo membrane contains leukocytes, fibrin and cellular debris.

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Analysis of each option: A. Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment – True
  • • Fidaxomicin is a macrocyclic antibiotic used orally to treat C. difficile infections. It is especially useful for preventing recurrence.
  • • B. IgM is diagnostic – False
  • • Diagnosis is not based on IgM antibodies. Instead, it relies on detection of C. difficile toxins (A and B) in stool via enzyme immunoassay (EIA), PCR, or toxigenic culture.
  • • C. It is toxin mediated – True
  • • The disease is caused by toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin) produced by C. difficile.
  • • D. Pseudomembrane contains leukocytes, fibrin and cellular debris – True
  • • Histologically, pseudomembranes consist of necrotic epithelial cells, leukocytes, fibrin, and mucus, forming the yellow-white plaques seen on colonoscopy.

questions.text: A patient was admitted due to sepsis and broad-spectrum antibiotic started. She developed diarrhea. What is used to identify the etiology of diarrhea ?
questions.correct_answer: B. GDH ag and toxin assay
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • To identify the etiology, the recommended initial testing strategy involves:
  • • Glutamate Dehydrogenase (GDH) Antigen + Toxin A/B Assay: GDH antigen: Detects the presence of C. difficile organism (high sensitivity).
  • • Toxin assay: Detects toxins A and B (high specificity, confirms pathogenic strain).
  • • This two-step algorithm increases diagnostic accuracy.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. GDH Ag only – Cannot differentiate between toxin-producing and non-toxigenic strains; high sensitivity but low specificity.
  • • C. Stool microscopy – Not useful for C. difficile; cannot detect toxins or differentiate species.
  • • D. Aerobic culture – C. difficile is anaerobic; and even anaerobic culture is time-consuming and not routinely used.

questions.text: A soldier presented with fever, myalgia, rash in body sparing palm and sole. Five other soldiers in the troop also affected with similar illness. H/o exposure to body lice present . Choose the correct Causative organism ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Key features pointing to R. prowazekii: Fever, myalgia, rash sparing palms and soles.
  • • Multiple cases in close quarters (suggests outbreak).
  • • Exposure to body lice — this is the primary vector for R. prowazekii.
  • • Seen in settings like military troops, refugee camps, or crowded unsanitary conditions.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Rickettsia typhi – Causes endemic (murine) typhus, transmitted by fleas, not lice.
  • • C. Rickettsia akari – Causes rickettsialpox, transmitted by mites; associated with papulovesicular rash.
  • • D. Rickettsia conorii – Causes Mediterranean spotted fever or Indian tick typhus, with rash involving palms and soles; transmitted by ticks, not lice.

questions.text: A diabetic patient had rhinitis, facial swelling. Biopsy showed aseptate hyphae with irregular obtuse branching. Drug of choice for this ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Key clues: Diabetic patient
  • • Rhinitis and facial swelling – typical early signs of rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis
  • • Biopsy: Aseptate hyphae with irregular, obtuse (broad-angle) branching – classic histological feature of Mucorales species (e.g., Rhizopus, Mucor, Rhizomucor)
  • • Treatment: First-line drug: Liposomal Amphotericin B
  • • Broad antifungal with activity against Mucorales
  • • Administered IV, often along with surgical debridement
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Fluconazole – Ineffective against Mucorales.
  • • C. Voriconazole – Active against Aspergillus, but not effective against Mucorales; may worsen prognosis if used mistakenly.
  • • D. Caspofungin – Echinocandins like caspofungin are not active against Mucorales.

questions.text: A 4-month-old child born to HIV positive mother developed recurrent diarrhea . What is the next step of management?

options.label: A
options.text: Stop breast feeding and start ART

options.label: D
options.text: Test for IgM antibodies of giardia and start antibiotics

questions.correct_answer: B. Dried blood for HIV PCR
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why? Maternal HIV antibodies cross the placenta and can remain in the infant's circulation for up to 18 months, making HIV antibody tests (Option C) unreliable in infants.
  • • HIV PCR (DNA or RNA) detects viral nucleic acids, making it the gold standard for early infant diagnosis (usually from 6 weeks of age).
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Stop breastfeeding and start ART – Premature. ART should be started only after confirming the diagnosis. Breastfeeding guidance depends on maternal ART status and local protocols.
  • • C. Test for HIV antibody – Not useful under 18 months due to maternal antibody interference.
  • • D. Test for Giardia IgM and start antibiotics – May be relevant later, but first priority is to assess for underlying HIV infection which predisposes to recurrent infections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer admitted with sinuses with discharging granules in the foot. Microscopy of the granule shown in the image. Choose the true statement

options.label: C
options.text: Caused by both bacteria and fungi

questions.correct_answer: C. Caused by both bacteria and fungi
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Microscopy of granules: These grains or granules are compact colonies of organisms surrounded by immune cells and tissue debris.
  • • Microscopy helps distinguish between actinomycetoma (bacterial) and eumycetoma (fungal).
  • • Key point: Mycetoma can be caused by:
  • • Bacteria – called actinomycetoma (e.g., Nocardia, Actinomadura, Streptomyces)
  • • Fungi – called eumycetoma (e.g., Madurella, Exophiala)
  • • Hence, it is true that mycetoma is caused by both bacteria and fungi.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. It causes only superficial disease – False. Mycetoma is chronic and deep, involving subcutaneous tissue, muscle, and even bone.
  • • B. Hematogenous spread – Rare. Mycetoma typically spreads locally, not through the bloodstream.
  • • D. Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon – Not a typical feature of mycetoma. This is seen in some parasitic or fungal infections like sporotrichosis, schistosomiasis, or eosinophilic granulomas, but not in mycetoma granules.

questions.text: Microfilariae with sheathed tail and two nucleus in the tail tip suggestive of
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Sheath presence
  • • Tail morphology
  • • Arrangement of nuclei in the tail
  • • Brugia malayi distinguishing features: Sheathed microfilariae
  • • Two discrete nuclei in the tail tip
  • • Tail is kinked, with terminal and subterminal nuclei distinctly separated
  • • These features help differentiate it from Wuchereria bancrofti, which also has a sheath but no nuclei in the tail tip.
  • • Comparison with other options: A. Loa loa – Sheathed, but nuclei extend to the tail tip continuously, not two distinct ones.
  • • C. Wuchereria bancrofti – Sheathed, but no nuclei at the tail tip.
  • • D. Mansonella ozzardi – Unsheathed, and no nuclei at the tail tip.

questions.text: Choose the correct MoA of botulinum toxin.

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibits the release of Acetyl choline

questions.correct_answer: B. Inhibits the release of Acetyl choline
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Mechanism of Action (MoA): It inhibits the release of acetylcholine (ACh) at the neuromuscular junction by cleaving SNARE proteins required for vesicle fusion.
  • • This leads to flaccid paralysis, as muscles are unable to contract.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Stimulate nicotinic receptors – Botulinum toxin doesn't stimulate receptors; it prevents neurotransmitter release.
  • • C. Stimulate muscarinic receptors – It does not act on receptors directly, nor stimulate parasympathetic responses.
  • • D. Stimulate the release of norepinephrine – Botulinum toxin affects cholinergic (ACh) neurons, not adrenergic ones.

questions.text: A patient admitted with fever, headache, vomiting, altered sensorium with neck rigidity. CSF analysis shows slight decrease in glucose and increase in proteins. Microscopy – predominantly lymphocytes seen. A coagulum of CSF seen as shown in the image. Choose the correct diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Key clues: Fever, headache, vomiting, altered sensorium, and neck rigidity — classic signs of meningitis
  • • CSF analysis:
  • • Slight decrease in glucose (moderate hypoglycorrhachia)
  • • Increased protein
  • • Predominantly lymphocytic pleocytosis
  • • Coagulum in CSF (often described as a "cobweb" or "spider web" clot) — this is characteristic of TB meningitis, due to high fibrin content in proteinaceous CSF
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Pyogenic meningitis – Usually shows markedly low glucose, very high protein, and predominantly neutrophils, not lymphocytes.
  • • B. Viral meningitis – Typically has normal glucose, mild protein elevation, and lymphocytes, but no CSF clot.
  • • D. Chemical meningitis – May resemble infectious meningitis, but lacks classic cobweb coagulum, and is usually a diagnosis of exclusion.

questions.text: MDR TB refers to resistant to
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Isoniazid (INH) and
  • • Rifampicin (RIF)
  • • These two drugs are the most powerful first-line anti-TB medications, and resistance to both constitutes MDR-TB.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Rifampicin + Kanamycin – Kanamycin is a second-line injectable drug. Resistance to it is not part of MDR-TB definition.
  • • B. Isoniazid + Rifampicin + Kanamycin – This represents pre-XDR or XDR-TB, not basic MDR-TB.
  • • D. Isoniazid + Fluoroquinolones – Resistance to fluoroquinolones plus MDR-TB defines pre-XDR TB, not MDR-TB alone.

questions.text: A 20 year female working in a village school developed watery diarrhea with rice water stool. The pathogen responsible for this condition acts on
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Pathogenesis of Cholera: Cholera toxin (CTX) is the main virulence factor.
  • • It is an AB? exotoxin, where:
  • • The B subunit binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on intestinal epithelial cells.
  • • The A subunit activates adenylate cyclase via ADP-ribosylation of Gs protein, increasing cAMP levels.
  • • This leads to massive secretion of chloride and water into the intestinal lumen → profuse watery diarrhea ("rice water stool").
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. GM2 ganglioside receptor – Associated with certain neurological toxins, not cholera.
  • • C. Cerebroganglioside receptor – Nonspecific and not involved in cholera.
  • • D. Sphingomyelin receptor – Not relevant to cholera toxin; more associated with some bacterial or viral infections (e.g., Listeria, Shiga toxin).

questions.text: Female came with a clinical condition as shown in the image. HPE shows she’s having high risk for squamous cell atypia. Which is responsible for this condition.
A patient came with unilateral lymphadenopathy. Sheathed Organism with no nuclei at the tail tip seen in the microscope. Choose the correct pathogen.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Wuchereria bancrofti is the most common cause of lymphatic filariasis, which typically presents as unilateral lymphadenopathy or lymphedema. The microfilariae of W. bancrofti are sheathed, and a key identifying feature on microscopy is that they have no nuclei at the tip of the tail (the tail tip is clear). This microscopic characteristic helps differentiate W. bancrofti from other filarial species. The clinical presentation and these microscopic findings strongly support W. bancrofti as the correct pathogen in this case.
  • • Incorrect Options: B. Brugia malayi: Brugia malayi microfilariae are sheathed but differ by having two distinct nuclei at the tail tip, which is not seen here. It also causes lymphatic filariasis but is less common and has different endemic areas.
  • • C. Loa loa: Loa loa microfilariae are sheathed and have nuclei extending continuously to the tail tip. Clinically, it causes calabar swellings and migrates through subcutaneous tissue rather than causing significant lymphadenopathy.
  • • D. Brugia timori: Brugia timori is another cause of lymphatic filariasis, endemic to limited regions, but its microfilariae have nuclei extending into the tail tip, unlike W. bancrofti.

questions.text: A clinician, clinically diagnosed a case of brucellosis, and ordered Standard agglutination test for brucellosis. It showed negative. But after serial dilution of serum, it become positive. Choose the Correct cause for this condition.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The prozone phenomenon occurs when there is an excess of antibodies in the serum, which interferes with the optimal formation of antigen-antibody complexes necessary for visible agglutination. In the context of the Standard Agglutination Test (SAT) for brucellosis, a very high antibody concentration can prevent agglutination from occurring, resulting in a false-negative test at lower dilutions. When the serum is serially diluted, the antibody concentration falls into the optimal range, allowing proper lattice formation and a positive agglutination test. This is a classic example of the prozone effect causing initial false-negative results.
  • • Incorrect Options: B. Post zone: The post zone phenomenon occurs when there is an excess of antigen relative to antibodies, which can also inhibit agglutination. However, this usually happens with antigen excess, not antibody excess, and is less common in serological tests like brucellosis SAT.
  • • C. Incomplete antibody: Incomplete antibodies (also called non-agglutinating antibodies) are antibodies that do not cause visible agglutination by themselves. They are not responsible for false-negative SAT results that become positive on dilution.
  • • D. Blocking antibody: Blocking antibodies interfere with the formation of visible immune complexes but are not typically the cause of dilution-dependent positivity in agglutination tests.

questions.text: A child admitted with fever, rash begins behind the ears, conjunctivitis, Coryza, cough and Koplik spot . Based on the clinical manifestations, choose the correct description of the pathogen.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The clinical presentation — fever, rash starting behind the ears, conjunctivitis, coryza, cough, and Koplik spots — is classic for measles.
  • • The causative agent of measles is the Measles virus, which belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family.
  • • It is a single-stranded (ss) RNA virus that is enveloped.
  • • The envelope helps the virus enter host cells and evade the immune system.
  • • The virus is negative-sense ssRNA, but the key point here is ssRNA and enveloped.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. ds enveloped RNA virus: Double-stranded RNA viruses are rare in humans and measles is not one of them. Also, no common dsRNA enveloped virus causes this clinical picture.
  • • C. ss naked RNA virus: Measles virus is enveloped, not naked. Naked ssRNA viruses include enteroviruses like poliovirus.
  • • D. ds naked RNA virus: There are no known dsRNA naked viruses causing measles-like illness.

questions.text: A patient from UP admitted with fever, hepatosplenomegaly. His Bone marrow biopsy shown the pathogen with kinetoplast. Choose the correct vector for this pathogen.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The clinical picture of fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and bone marrow biopsy revealing a pathogen with a kinetoplast is characteristic of Leishmaniasis. The kinetoplast is a distinctive DNA-containing structure found in certain protozoa of the family Trypanosomatidae, which includes Leishmania species.
  • • The vector for Leishmania species is the Sandfly (genus Phlebotomus in the Old World, including India).
  • • The disease caused, especially in places like UP (Uttar Pradesh), is Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar).
  • • The parasite multiplies inside macrophages and is identifiable on bone marrow smear or biopsy by its kinetoplast.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Tsetse fly: Vector for Trypanosoma brucei, the causative agent of African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness). Not found in India and does not cause Leishmaniasis.
  • • C. Female Anopheles mosquito: Vector for Plasmodium species causing malaria. Malaria parasites do not have kinetoplasts.
  • • D. Triatome infestans: Vector for Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease in South America. Not relevant here.

questions.text: A child admitted with bloody diarrhoea with one day duration. The pathogen is obligate aerobe. Choose the correct enrichment medium for the pathogen.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The clinical presentation of bloody diarrhea lasting for one day suggests infection with Shigella or Salmonella species. Among these, Shigella is a facultative anaerobe but is often isolated using enrichment media designed to suppress competing gut flora.
  • • Selenite F broth is a selective enrichment medium specifically designed to enhance the growth of Salmonella and Shigella from stool samples by inhibiting competing bacteria.
  • • It favors the growth of these pathogens, facilitating their isolation on subsequent plating.
  • • Since the pathogen is obligate aerobe in the question (note: Shigella and Salmonella are facultative anaerobes, but the question likely emphasizes enrichment for a pathogen causing bloody diarrhea and requiring this medium), selenite F broth is commonly used for Salmonella and Shigella.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Alkaline peptone water: Used as enrichment for Vibrio species, particularly Vibrio cholerae, which causes watery diarrhea, not bloody diarrhea.
  • • B. RCM (Reinforced Clostridial Medium): Selective for Clostridium species, anaerobic bacteria that cause different diseases (like gas gangrene, pseudomembranous colitis).
  • • D. BHI broth (Brain Heart Infusion broth): General-purpose nutrient broth, not selective or enrichment for enteric pathogens causing bloody diarrhea.

questions.text: A patient presents with Painless indurated ulcer on his penis with non tender lymphadenopathy. Motility of the organism best visualized by
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The clinical presentation of a painless indurated ulcer on the penis with non-tender lymphadenopathy is classic for primary syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. This bacterium is a spirochete, which is thin and spiral-shaped, making it difficult to visualize with standard light microscopy.
  • • The dark field microscope is the best tool to visualize the motility of Treponema pallidum in clinical specimens such as lesion exudate.
  • • It enhances contrast by illuminating the specimen against a dark background, allowing the delicate, thin spirochetes to be seen clearly moving.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Light microscope: Regular light microscopy cannot easily visualize Treponema pallidum due to its thinness and transparency.
  • • B. Electron microscope: Electron microscopy provides very high resolution but is impractical for routine clinical diagnosis and does not visualize motility.
  • • D. Fluorescent microscope: Used for specific fluorescent antibody staining but not for observing motility in routine clinical settings.

questions.text: Culture isolate from a patient with 70% burns is obligate aerobe. It shows positive for the test shown in the image. Choose the correct pathogen
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In patients with severe burns (70% body surface), Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common and serious opportunistic pathogen that frequently causes infections.
  • • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an obligate aerobe, meaning it requires oxygen to grow.
  • • It produces a positive oxidase test (the test likely shown in your image), which distinguishes it from many other gram-negative rods like E. coli and Proteus species.
  • • It also forms characteristic greenish-blue pigments (pyocyanin) and has a fruity odor in culture.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Escherichia coli: Facultative anaerobe and oxidase negative.
  • • C. Proteus vulgaris: Facultative anaerobe and oxidase negative.
  • • D. Neisseria meningitidis: Oxidase positive but is a diplococcus usually causing meningitis, not common in burn wound infections. Also, not an obligate aerobe like Pseudomonas.

questions.text: Two friends developed vomiting after had dinner in the party. They ate many items except pastry. Next day they had vomiting. Which organism involved?
questions.correct_answer: A. Emetic toxin of Bacillus cereus
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The scenario describes vomiting occurring after eating at a party, with onset within hours (next day, likely within 1–6 hours), and the fact that they ate multiple items except pastry. This is classic for Bacillus cereus food poisoning caused by the emetic toxin.
  • • The emetic form of Bacillus cereus intoxication is associated with fried rice and pasta (starchy foods), but the question implies that they avoided pastry, which commonly is associated with this toxin. The incubation period is short (1-6 hours), and symptoms are mainly nausea and vomiting.
  • • Bacillus cereus produces a heat-stable emetic toxin that causes this rapid onset vomiting.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Staphylococcal enterotoxin: Causes food poisoning with vomiting and diarrhea, usually within 1–6 hours, often associated with contaminated dairy or meat products but the question highlights avoidance of pastry, which is typical for Bacillus cereus emetic toxin.
  • • C. Shigella toxin: Causes dysentery and bloody diarrhea, not rapid vomiting after a meal.
  • • D. E. coli Labile toxin: Causes watery diarrhea (traveler’s diarrhea) with longer incubation, not vomiting.

questions.text: A PLHIV came with fever, cough with sputum and rigor. His CD4 count is 55mm3. On examination, there is coarse respiratory sound in right lower lobe and x ray shows right lower lobe consolidation. Choose the correct pathogen?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A PLHIV (person living with HIV) with a CD4 count of 55/mm³ is severely immunocompromised.
  • • The patient presents with fever, productive cough with sputum, rigors, and right lower lobe consolidation on chest X-ray.
  • • This clinical picture is consistent with bacterial pneumonia, and among common pathogens, Streptococcus pneumoniae (Pneumococci) is the most frequent cause of community-acquired pneumonia, including in HIV patients.
  • • Pneumococcal pneumonia typically presents acutely with fever, productive cough, rigors, and lobar consolidation.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Staphylococcus aureus: Can cause pneumonia, often post-influenza or in hospital settings, and may cause cavitary lesions. Not the most common cause here.
  • • C. Pneumocystis jiroveci: Classically causes interstitial pneumonia (PCP), with non-productive cough, gradual onset, and diffuse bilateral infiltrates on X-ray, not lobar consolidation.
  • • D. Mycoplasma: Causes atypical pneumonia, often in young adults with non-productive cough, mild symptoms, and patchy infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation.

questions.text: A patient presented with recurrent urticaria with eosinophilia. BAL shows numerous small larvae in microscopy. Choose the correct pathogen.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The presentation of recurrent urticaria with eosinophilia suggests a parasitic infection with an allergic or hypersensitivity component.
  • • The presence of numerous small larvae in BAL (bronchoalveolar lavage) microscopy indicates the larval migratory phase through the lungs, typical of Strongyloides stercoralis.
  • • Strongyloides has a unique life cycle that includes autoinfection and larval migration through the lungs causing Löffler’s syndrome, presenting with respiratory symptoms and eosinophilia.
  • • The larva seen in BAL confirms pulmonary involvement by Strongyloides.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Enterobius vermicularis: Causes perianal itching; no lung migration or larvae in BAL.
  • • C. Ancylostoma caninum: Primarily a dog hookworm; human infection causes cutaneous larva migrans, not pulmonary larval migration or BAL larvae.
  • • D. Capillaria philippinensis: Causes intestinal capillariasis with diarrhea and malabsorption, no pulmonary phase with larvae in BAL.

questions.text: Hair perforation test is positive in
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The hair perforation test is a laboratory test used to differentiate dermatophyte species based on their ability to perforate hair shafts in vitro.
  • • Trichophyton mentagrophytes produces positive hair perforation test results by causing grooves or perforations on the hair cuticle.
  • • This characteristic helps distinguish it from other species that do not show this behavior.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Trichophyton rubrum: Usually shows a negative hair perforation test; it does not produce significant hair perforations.
  • • C. Microsporum audouinii: Does not perforate hair in this test; it generally invades hair differently and is negative in hair perforation test.
  • • D. Epidermophyton floccosum: Does not infect hair; it primarily infects skin and nails, so the test is negative.

questions.text: Patient develops sudden onset of fever, headache, chills, and weakness and swollen, tender and painful lymph nodes with blackish discoloration of peripheral limbs. Clinician suspected a bacterial etiology which rat is the reservoir. Choose the correct vector for this condition.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The clinical presentation of sudden fever, headache, chills, weakness, swollen tender lymph nodes (bubo), and blackish discoloration of peripheral limbs is characteristic of plague.
  • • The bacterium Yersinia pestis is the causative agent of plague.
  • • Rats are the primary reservoirs of Yersinia pestis.
  • • The vector transmitting plague from rats to humans is the rat flea, Xenopsylla species.
  • • The flea bites humans and transmits the bacteria, causing bubonic plague (lymphadenopathy with bubo) and can lead to septicemic plague, which explains the blackish discoloration (gangrene) of extremities.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Triatome species: Vector of Trypanosoma cruzi causing Chagas disease, not plague.
  • • C. Aedes aegypti: Mosquito vector for dengue, chikungunya, yellow fever, not plague.
  • • D. Simulium fly: Vector for Onchocerca volvulus (river blindness), not plague.

questions.text: A pregnant women came to contact with a varicella patient. Her antibody is tested for VZA and was negative. Choose the correct statement.

options.label: B
options.text: She is susceptible to develop chickenpox

questions.correct_answer: B. She is susceptible to develop chickenpox
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The patient is pregnant and had contact with a varicella (chickenpox) patient.
  • • Her antibody test for Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) is negative, meaning no immunity.
  • • Since she has no antibodies, she is susceptible to primary infection, which is chickenpox.
  • • Chickenpox during pregnancy can cause serious complications for both mother and fetus, so identifying susceptibility is important.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. She is susceptible to zoster: Zoster (shingles) results from reactivation of latent VZV in someone previously infected. If she is seronegative, she never had primary infection, so she cannot get shingles yet.
  • • C. She is immune to chickenpox: Negative antibody means no immunity, so this is incorrect.
  • • D. She is immune to zoster: Immunity to zoster requires prior chickenpox infection; she is seronegative, so no immunity.

questions.text: There is a blood spill in Operation theater. Choose the correct agent used to clean the blood spill.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In healthcare settings, blood spills pose a risk of transmitting blood-borne pathogens like HIV, HBV, and HCV.
  • • Sodium hypochlorite (bleach) is the preferred disinfectant for cleaning blood spills because it is a broad-spectrum, fast-acting, and effective agent that kills viruses, bacteria, and spores.
  • • It is commonly used in a concentration of 1:10 dilution (10%) for blood spills to ensure proper disinfection.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Lysol: A general disinfectant, but not as effective or recommended specifically for blood spills, especially for blood-borne viruses.
  • • B. Quaternary ammonium compounds: Effective against many bacteria but less effective against viruses, and not recommended for blood spills.
  • • D. Cresol: Phenolic compound, used as a disinfectant but less common and more toxic, not preferred for blood spills.

questions.text: A male presented with the following finding as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Clinically, it presents with purulent urethral discharge, often yellowish or greenish, and dysuria (painful urination).
  • • The image likely shows a male patient with urethral discharge, which is classic for gonorrhoea.
  • • Gonorrhoea commonly causes acute onset of symptoms, and the discharge is typically thick, purulent, and profuse.
  • • Diagnosis can be confirmed by Gram stain showing Gram-negative intracellular diplococci and culture.
  • • Why other options are less likely: B. Herpes: Herpes simplex virus causes painful vesicles and ulcers on the genitalia, not purulent discharge.
  • • C. Syphilis: Primary syphilis presents as a painless ulcer (chancre), not with purulent urethral discharge.
  • • D. Ureaplasma: Ureaplasma infection may cause non-gonococcal urethritis with mild discharge, often less purulent and less acute.

questions.text: Which of the following is the vector for zika virus?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Zika virus is primarily transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito.
  • • This mosquito is a daytime feeder and also transmits other viruses such as dengue and chikungunya.
  • • The mosquito breeds in stagnant water found around human habitation, making it an urban vector.
  • • Zika virus infection is associated with fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and in pregnant women, it can cause microcephaly in the fetus.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Phlebotomus: Vector for Leishmania parasites causing leishmaniasis, not Zika virus.
  • • C. Culex: Vector for West Nile virus and some encephalitis viruses, not primarily Zika.
  • • D. Anopheles: Vector for malaria parasites (Plasmodium species), not Zika virus.

questions.text: A man from a tribal area of Jharkhand reports with fever for last 3 days. Peripheral blood is collected and stained with Giemsa. A diagnosis as malaria is made. The smear is shown in the fig. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Plasmodium falciparum is the most severe form of malaria and is common in many parts of India, including tribal areas like Jharkhand.
  • • On Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear, P. falciparum shows:
  • • Multiple ring forms inside a single red blood cell (RBC).
  • • "Banana-shaped" or crescent-shaped gametocytes (a distinctive feature).
  • • Often, trophozoites are delicate rings with one or two chromatin dots.
  • • RBCs usually appear normal in size (no enlargement or stippling).
  • • Absence of schizonts and mature trophozoites in peripheral blood because they sequester in deep tissues.
  • • The clinical picture of fever for 3 days, plus the presence of typical features on smear, supports P. falciparum infection.
  • • Why other options are less likely: B. P. vivax: Shows enlarged RBCs with amoeboid trophozoites and Schuffner’s dots; gametocytes are round or oval, not banana-shaped.
  • • C. P. malariae: Has band forms in RBCs and rosette schizonts; RBCs usually not enlarged.
  • • D. P. ovale: Causes oval, enlarged RBCs with fimbriated edges; less common in India.

questions.text: A 12 years old boy presents with vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The boy developed vomiting within 3 hours of eating food at a party.
  • • This rapid onset of symptoms is typical of Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning, which is caused by ingestion of preformed enterotoxins in contaminated food.
  • • The incubation period for S. aureus toxin is usually 1 to 6 hours, with vomiting as the predominant symptom.
  • • Common foods involved include cream-filled pastries, custards, and mayonnaise-based salads.
  • • Why other options are less likely: A. Salmonella: Has a longer incubation period (6 to 48 hours) and typically causes diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps rather than isolated vomiting.
  • • B. Clostridium botulinum: Causes botulism characterized by neurological symptoms such as blurred vision, muscle weakness, not just vomiting.
  • • D. Clostridium perfringens: Usually causes diarrhea and abdominal cramps after 8 to 16 hours, vomiting is less common and onset is slower.

questions.text: An HIV positive patient with a CD4 count of 300/cumm presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the figure. On microscopy budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The patient is HIV positive with a CD4 count of 300/cumm, which puts them at risk for opportunistic infections.
  • • The mucosal lesions in the mouth combined with microscopy showing budding yeasts and pseudohyphae is characteristic of oral candidiasis.
  • • Candida albicans is the most common cause of oral candidiasis, presenting as white plaques that can be wiped off, leaving an erythematous base.
  • • Oral candidiasis is common in immunocompromised patients, including those with HIV infection.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Oral hairy leukoplakia: Caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), presents as white, non-removable, corrugated patches on the lateral tongue, but no yeasts or pseudohyphae on microscopy.
  • • C. Lichen planus: A chronic inflammatory condition showing white lacy patches or erosions in the mouth, but no fungal elements on microscopy.
  • • D. Vitamin deficiency: May cause mucosal changes like glossitis or stomatitis but not budding yeasts or pseudohyphae.

questions.text: Superantigens not produced by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Superantigens are exotoxins that can non-specifically activate a large population of T cells by binding to MHC class II and T-cell receptors outside the conventional antigen-binding site, leading to massive cytokine release and systemic effects like toxic shock.
  • • Staphylococcus aureus produces several superantigens including Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin-1 (TSST-1) and enterotoxins responsible for food poisoning.
  • • Streptococcus pyogenes produces superantigens called streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins which are implicated in scarlet fever and streptococcal toxic shock syndrome.
  • • Clostridium perfringens produces toxins (like alpha-toxin), but it is not typically classified as a major producer of superantigens. However, some strains can produce toxins with superantigen-like activity.
  • • Staphylococcus epidermidis is a coagulase-negative staphylococcus and is generally not known to produce superantigens. It is mostly associated with biofilm-related infections on prosthetic devices but lacks the typical exotoxins and superantigens produced by S. aureus.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Streptococcus pyogenes: Produces streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins (superantigens).
  • • B. Clostridium perfringens: Though mainly known for other toxins, some strains can have superantigen-like toxins.
  • • C. Staphylococcus aureus: Well-known producer of several superantigens like TSST-1.

questions.text: Which of the following is a category A bioterrorism agent?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Category A bioterrorism agents are those organisms or toxins that pose the highest risk to national security because they:
  • • Can be easily disseminated or transmitted from person to person.
  • • Result in high mortality rates and have the potential for major public health impact.
  • • Might cause public panic and require special preparedness.
  • • Bacillus anthracis, the causative agent of anthrax, is classified as a Category A agent by the CDC. It can form spores that survive harsh conditions, be aerosolized, and cause severe disease with high fatality if untreated. It has been historically used as a bioweapon.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Coxiella burnetii: Causes Q fever, a zoonotic disease, but is classified as a Category B agent due to moderate ease of dissemination and lower mortality.
  • • B. Brucella species: Cause brucellosis, also a Category B agent due to moderate impact and transmission.
  • • C. Nipah virus: An emerging zoonotic virus with high mortality but currently not classified as Category A by CDC for bioterrorism.

questions.text: Which of the following help in bacterial adhesion to host cells?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Fimbriae (also called pili) are hair-like proteinaceous appendages on the surface of many bacteria.
  • • They are primarily responsible for attachment (adhesion) to host cells by binding to specific receptors on the host tissue.
  • • This adhesion is the first step in colonization and infection.
  • • Examples include Escherichia coli fimbriae that help it attach to urinary tract epithelium.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Cytoplasmic membrane: The inner membrane that controls transport and metabolic processes but is not involved in direct adhesion to host cells.
  • • B. Mesosomes: Infoldings of the bacterial plasma membrane seen in some bacteria (likely an artifact) with no role in adhesion.
  • • D. LPS (Lipopolysaccharide): Part of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, important for immune activation and structural integrity, but not involved in adhesion.

questions.text: The selective medium for E.coli 0157:H7 is?

options.label: C
options.text: Thiosulfate citrate bile salt sucrose agar

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • E. coli O157:H7 is a Shiga toxin-producing strain and an important cause of hemorrhagic colitis.
  • • Unlike most E. coli strains, O157:H7 cannot ferment sorbitol.
  • • Sorbitol MacConkey (SMAC) agar is a selective and differential medium designed to isolate E. coli O157:H7:
  • • Most E. coli strains ferment sorbitol and produce pink/red colonies.
  • • E. coli O157:H7 colonies remain colorless or pale because they do not ferment sorbitol.
  • • This property helps distinguish O157:H7 from other E. coli strains.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Xylose Lysine Deoxycholate agar: Used primarily for Salmonella and Shigella isolation, not for E. coli O157:H7.
  • • C. Thiosulfate citrate bile salt sucrose (TCBS) agar: Selective medium for Vibrio species (like Vibrio cholerae), unrelated to E. coli.
  • • D. Thayer Martin medium: Selective medium for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Neisseria meningitidis, not E. coli.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common soil transmitted helminthic infection in India characterized by eggs in stool as shown in the figure?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) is a common soil-transmitted helminth in India and many tropical countries.
  • • The diagnosis is often made by identifying characteristic eggs in stool microscopy.
  • • The eggs of Trichuris are barrel-shaped or football-shaped with bipolar plugs (clear protrusions at both ends).
  • • These eggs are quite distinctive and help differentiate Trichuris from other helminths.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Ascaris: Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are oval and have a thick, rough outer shell with a mammillated surface but lack bipolar plugs.
  • • C. Enterobius: Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) eggs are small, oval, and flattened on one side, typically diagnosed by perianal swab rather than stool microscopy.
  • • D. Ancylostoma: Ancylostoma (hookworm) eggs are oval with thin shells and contain developing embryos; morphology differs from Trichuris.

questions.text: Antimicrobial property of bleaching powder is due to
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • HOCl is a strong oxidizing agent that penetrates microbial cell walls and denatures proteins, enzymes, and nucleic acids, effectively killing bacteria, viruses, and fungi.
  • • It is more effective than chlorine gas or other chlorine compounds due to its neutral charge, which allows better interaction with negatively charged microbial surfaces.
  • • Bleaching powder, when dissolved in water, forms:
  • • scss Copy Edit Ca(OCl)? + H?O → Ca²? + 2HOCl Incorrect Options: B. Chloroform: Not related to the action of bleaching powder. Chloroform is a solvent, not an antimicrobial agent derived from bleach.
  • • C. Chlorine: While chlorine is released from bleaching powder, it is the HOCl (formed from chlorine in water) that provides the actual antimicrobial effect, not elemental chlorine itself.
  • • D. H? (Hydrogen ion): H? is not directly responsible for antimicrobial activity. Although pH affects the equilibrium between HOCl and OCl?, it is HOCl that has the potent antimicrobial action.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of donovanosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis), a Gram-negative intracellular bacillus.
  • • It produces Donovan bodies, which are safety-pin-shaped intracellular inclusions seen within macrophages on Giemsa or Wright stain.
  • • The infection causes granulomatous inflammation, leading to beefy red ulcers that bleed easily.
  • • Incorrect Options: A. Haemophilus ducreyi Causes chancroid, a painful genital ulcer with painful lymphadenopathy (bubo). Unlike donovanosis, chancroid is acute and often associated with suppurative inguinal nodes.
  • • C. Leishmania donovani Causes visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), not genital ulcers. It affects internal organs like the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.
  • • D. Treponema pallidum Causes syphilis, which typically presents with a painless genital chancre and generalized rash in secondary stage. Spirochete seen on dark field microscopy.

questions.text: Urethritis in males is not caused by
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The most common causes of urethritis include: Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Gonococcus): A classic cause of purulent urethritis.
  • • Chlamydia trachomatis: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU).
  • • Trichomonas vaginalis: A protozoan parasite that can cause nongonococcal urethritis in males, often asymptomatic but still transmissible.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Haemophilus ducreyi This organism causes chancroid, a painful genital ulcer, not urethritis. It does not invade the urethral epithelium or produce urethral symptoms directly.
  • • B. Trichomonas vaginalis Though more common in females, it can cause urethritis in males, sometimes asymptomatic but detectable on urethral swabs or urine microscopy.
  • • C. Chlamydia trachomatis One of the leading causes of urethritis, particularly nongonococcal urethritis. Often presents with mild or no symptoms.
  • • D. Neisseria gonorrhoeae A classic and common cause of urethritis, especially purulent urethritis with thick yellow discharge.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be acquired by traumatic inoculation?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Mode of transmission: Classically acquired by traumatic inoculation, such as:
  • • A thorn prick
  • • Splinters
  • • Animal scratches (especially from cats)
  • • Clinical presentation:
  • • Begins as a painless papule at the site of inoculation.
  • • May spread along lymphatics causing nodular lymphangitis, presenting as a chain of nodules.
  • • ? Explanation (Incorrect Options): A. Blastomyces dermatitidis Typically acquired by inhalation of spores, not trauma. It causes pulmonary disease and may disseminate to skin, bones, and GU tract.
  • • C. Coccidioides immitis Also acquired through inhalation, especially in arid regions like the southwestern U.S. Causes Valley fever (coccidioidomycosis). No link to traumatic entry.
  • • D. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis Found in South America, typically acquired through inhalation of conidia. Leads to a chronic granulomatous disease primarily affecting lungs and mucous membranes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about J.E?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Humans are dead-end hosts, not reservoirs. This is because the level of viremia in humans is too low to infect mosquitoes, hence humans do not contribute to further transmission of the virus.
  • • Explanation (Incorrect Options): B. Pigs are amplifier hosts True. Pigs develop high-level viremia and can efficiently amplify the virus, making them important in the transmission cycle.
  • • C. Transmitted by Culex vishnui True. The Culex vishnui subgroup, including Culex tritaeniorhynchus, is a major vector of J.E., especially in rural and peri-urban areas.
  • • D. Vaccination of pigs controls transmission True. Vaccinating pigs or separating them from human habitats reduces the amplification and thus the spread of the virus to humans.

questions.text: In renal transplant recipients, which is likely organism causing reactivation disease within 1-4 months after surgery?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • CMV can reactivate from latency due to immunosuppression.
  • • It causes a systemic illness with fever, malaise, leukopenia, and organ involvement (e.g., colitis, pneumonitis, retinitis).
  • • CMV also contributes to graft rejection and increased susceptibility to other infections.
  • • Preemptive therapy or prophylaxis is often used in high-risk patients (CMV-seropositive donor to seronegative recipient).
  • • Explanation of Incorrect Options: A. EBV (Epstein–Barr Virus): While EBV can reactivate, it is more often associated with Post-Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disorder (PTLD), which typically occurs later (after 6 months or more).
  • • C. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): HSV reactivation usually occurs early (within the first month) post-transplant and is generally localized (e.g., mucocutaneous lesions), not systemic.
  • • D. VZV (Varicella-Zoster Virus): VZV reactivation (as shingles) is less common in the early post-transplant period and usually occurs months to years later when cellular immunity wanes further.

questions.text: A child develops septic shock following meningitis. On examination the child has a petechial rash on shown in the figure. Which of the following is a gram negative diplococcus that can be the likely etiology?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Septic shock
  • • Petechial or purpuric rash (due to endotoxin-induced capillary leakage and DIC)
  • • Rapid progression to multiorgan failure if untreated
  • • The presence of petechial rash in a child with meningitis is highly characteristic of meningococcal sepsis.
  • • Explanation of Incorrect Options: A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa Though a gram-negative bacillus and a cause of sepsis, especially in immunocompromised individuals or burn patients, it is not a diplococcus and typically does not cause meningitis with a petechial rash.
  • • C. Streptococcus pneumoniae A common cause of meningitis but it is a Gram-positive diplococcus, not Gram-negative, and doesn't typically cause a petechial rash.
  • • D. E. coli A Gram-negative bacillus, often causing neonatal meningitis and urinary tract infections. It is not a diplococcus and rarely associated with a petechial rash.

questions.text: Nosocomial infection after how many hours of hospitalization?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Develops 48 hours or more after hospital admission,
  • • Was not present or incubating at the time of admission.
  • • This 48-hour time frame helps distinguish community-acquired infections from those acquired in the hospital setting due to exposure to hospital flora, invasive procedures, or immunocompromised states.
  • • Common examples include:
  • • Catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI)
  • • Central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSI)
  • • Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
  • • Surgical site infections (SSI)
  • • Explanation of Incorrect Options: B. 72 hrs While some guidelines may use this time point for specific infections (e.g., ventilator-associated pneumonia), the general definition of nosocomial infection starts at 48 hours.
  • • C. 96 hrs This is beyond the standard cutoff; not used in accepted definitions for nosocomial infections.
  • • D. 7 days Too late — many infections would be categorized as nosocomial well before this time point.

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the intestine are caused by
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • These ulcers have a narrow neck at the mucosal surface and broad base extending into the submucosa.
  • • Histologically, you can find trophozoites of E. histolytica with ingested red blood cells (RBCs), which is diagnostic.
  • • Explanation of Incorrect Options: A. Giardia lamblia Causes non-invasive infection, mostly limited to the small intestine, leading to malabsorption and steatorrhea, not ulcer formation.
  • • C. Helicobacter pylori Associated with gastric and duodenal ulcers, but not the flask-shaped colonic ulcers. It colonizes the stomach and leads to peptic ulcer disease.
  • • D. Enterobius vermicularis Also known as pinworm, it causes perianal itching, not intestinal ulcers. It resides in the colon and rectum but does not invade tissue to cause ulceration.

questions.text: Which of the following is the culture medium used for Legionella?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • BCYE medium contains:
  • • L-cysteine and iron salts, which are essential for Legionella's growth.
  • • Charcoal, which neutralizes toxic compounds.
  • • Colonies typically appear after 3–5 days of incubation in humidified conditions.
  • • This medium is the gold standard for the isolation of Legionella from clinical specimens like sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage, or lung biopsy.
  • • Explanation of Incorrect Options: B. MacConkey agar Used for gram-negative enteric bacilli like E. coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, etc. Legionella does not grow on MacConkey.
  • • C. Baird Parker agar Selective medium for the isolation of Staphylococcus aureus, not suitable for Legionella.
  • • D. Sabouraud dextrose agar Commonly used for fungal cultures, not appropriate for bacterial species like Legionella.

questions.text: Special stain used for Cryptococcus is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The capsule is a key virulence factor and helps in diagnosis.
  • • Mucicarmine stain is the best stain for visualizing the capsule of Cryptococcus.
  • • Explanation of Incorrect Options: A. ZN stain (Ziehl-Neelsen stain) Used primarily for acid-fast bacteria like Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It does not stain Cryptococcus.
  • • B. Gram stain Cryptococcus can be gram-positive, but the capsule is not visualized well by Gram stain.
  • • D. Malachite green Used as a spore stain (e.g., for Bacillus species). It does not highlight Cryptococcus capsules.

questions.text: A 36 years old male patient complains of cough, cold, fever. His sputum is rusty and is negative for TB. He has a history of travel to china and had consumed crab. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Clinical features: Patients present with cough, rusty sputum (blood-tinged), fever, and chest pain — symptoms mimicking pulmonary tuberculosis.
  • • Diagnosis: Sputum may contain characteristic eggs of Paragonimus. Sputum is negative for TB, but clinical features and history of crab consumption support paragonimiasis.
  • • Explanation of Other Options (Incorrect): B. Fasciola hepatica Causes fascioliasis, primarily a liver fluke infection affecting the liver and bile ducts, not the lungs. Transmitted by ingestion of watercress, not crab.
  • • C. Fasciolopsis buski Large intestinal fluke causing gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea and malabsorption, not respiratory symptoms.
  • • D. Entamoeba histolytica Causes amoebic dysentery and liver abscess but not respiratory symptoms or rusty sputum.

questions.text: Microbiological test for diagnosing Leptospira infection is?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • How it works: Patient serum is mixed with live cultures of different Leptospira serovars. If antibodies are present, they agglutinate (clump) the bacteria, which can be seen under the microscope.
  • • Why it is preferred: It is highly specific and sensitive, allowing identification of the infecting serovar and confirmation of diagnosis.
  • • Explanation of Other Options (Incorrect): A. Cold agglutination Used primarily to diagnose Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection, not Leptospira.
  • • B. Standard agglutination This refers to simpler agglutination tests, but MAT is a specialized microscopic agglutination test with live organisms, which is more specific.
  • • D. None of the above Incorrect because MAT is a recognized, standard diagnostic test.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown below:
Disc diffusion method is also known as
Rubella virus belongs to which family?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • It is the only member of the Rubivirus genus within the Togaviridae family.
  • • It causes German measles (rubella), which is usually mild but can cause congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) if infection occurs during pregnancy.
  • • Incorrect options: A. Reoviridae: Includes rotaviruses, double-stranded RNA viruses.
  • • C. Picornaviridae: Includes poliovirus, rhinovirus, and enteroviruses.
  • • D. Orthomyxoviridae: Includes influenza viruses.
  • • Let me know if you want a comparison chart of virus families!

questions.text: A 6 years old boy is having symptoms of fever with chills, cough, rapid breathing and chest pain. Culture from sample shows gram positive cocci. Identify the organism from the image given below-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Fever with chills
  • • Cough, rapid breathing, chest pain
  • • All suggest lobar pneumonia, which is common in children.
  • • Lab findings:
  • • Gram-positive cocci
  • • Typically appear as lancet-shaped diplococci on microscopy.
  • • Culture often shows colonies that are alpha-hemolytic on blood agar.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Staphylococcus aureus: Also gram-positive cocci, but typically appears in grape-like clusters, and causes more abscess-forming or cavitating pneumonias.
  • • C. Propionibacterium (Cutibacterium acnes): Gram-positive rod; anaerobic; part of skin flora—not typically a cause of pneumonia.
  • • D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Acid-fast bacillus, not gram-positive cocci; causes chronic, not acute, pneumonia-like symptoms.

questions.text: Diagnostic test for neurosyphilis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • It detects non-treponemal antibodies produced in response to T. pallidum infection in the central nervous system.
  • • Though less sensitive, it is highly specific when positive in CSF.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin): Also a non-treponemal test, but not validated for CSF testing, so not used for neurosyphilis diagnosis.
  • • C. TPI (Treponema pallidum immobilization test): Historical, complex, and not commonly used now; not specific for neurosyphilis.
  • • D. Weil-Felix test: Used for rickettsial infections, not syphilis.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in given image
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Characteristic features visible in the image (even though not shown here, based on typical case presentations):
  • • Grouped vesicles on an erythematous base
  • • Unilateral distribution, typically following a dermatomal pattern
  • • Associated with burning pain or tingling before the rash appears
  • • Most common in older adults or immunocompromised individuals
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Smallpox: Lesions are centrifugal (more on face/extremities), all lesions are in the same stage of development.
  • • C. Chickenpox (Varicella): Lesions are centripetal (more on trunk), appear in crops with different stages (macules, papules, vesicles, crusts) present simultaneously.
  • • D. Atopic dermatitis: Chronic, itchy, non-vesicular rash; typically in flexural areas in children.

questions.text: True about triad of congenital rubella syndrome is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) – a common congenital heart defect.
  • • Cataracts – due to virus-induced damage to developing lenses.
  • • Sensorineural deafness – the most common and often permanent complication.
  • • These are hallmark findings when rubella infection occurs during the first trimester of pregnancy.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Hepatosplenomegaly, mental retardation, deafness → Hepatosplenomegaly may occur but is not part of the classic triad.
  • • C. Chorioretinitis, multiorgan failure, pneumonitis → This is more typical of congenital CMV or toxoplasmosis, not rubella.
  • • D. None of the above → Incorrect because Option A correctly lists the triad.

questions.text: A patient is having gastrointestinal symptoms such as pain abdomen and distension, bloody and mucus diarrhoea and tenesmus with rectal prolapse. A stool microscopy reveals the presence of typical barrel shaped eggs. Possible causative agent is?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Gastrointestinal symptoms: abdominal pain, bloating, bloody and mucus-containing diarrhea.
  • • Tenesmus: frequent urge to defecate with little stool passage.
  • • Rectal prolapse: particularly in children with heavy worm burden.
  • • Stool microscopy shows typical barrel-shaped (lemon-shaped) eggs with bipolar plugs — pathognomonic for T. trichiura.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Campylobacter: Causes bacterial gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea, but does not produce barrel-shaped eggs in stool.
  • • B. Giardia lamblia: Causes non-bloody, foul-smelling, greasy diarrhea; no mucus or blood, and eggs/cysts are oval-shaped, not barrel-shaped.
  • • C. Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm): Causes perianal itching, not typically bloody diarrhea or rectal prolapse, and eggs are asymmetrical with a flattened side.

questions.text: Coxsackie A16 virus causes which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Key features of HFMD: Fever, followed by a vesicular rash on the hands, feet, and mouth.
  • • Common in children <5 years old.
  • • Usually mild and self-limiting, but can rarely lead to complications.
  • • Note: Enterovirus 71 can also cause HFMD and is more often associated with neurological complications.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Yellow fever: Caused by a Flavivirus, transmitted by mosquitoes.
  • • C. Rocky Mountain spotted fever: Caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, a bacterial infection.
  • • D. Myocarditis: More commonly caused by Coxsackie B virus, not A16.

questions.text: Following is the peripheral blood smear of a patient. Which of the following vector is involved in transmission?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In malaria: The peripheral smear typically shows trophozoites, schizonts, or gametocytes of Plasmodium spp.
  • • The disease is transmitted by the female Anopheles mosquito.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Ixodid tick: Vector for diseases like Lyme disease and Babesiosis, not malaria.
  • • C. Tsetse fly: Transmits Trypanosoma brucei, causing African sleeping sickness.
  • • D. Sandfly: Transmits Leishmania, causing leishmaniasis, not malaria.

questions.text: Australia antigen in context of hepatitis is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • It is a surface protein of the Hepatitis B virus (HBV).
  • • Presence of HBsAg in blood indicates an active HBV infection (either acute or chronic).
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. HBcAg: Core antigen; not detectable in serum, only in infected liver cells.
  • • C. HBeAg: Indicates active viral replication and high infectivity, but it's different from the surface antigen.
  • • D. Anti-HBeAg: Indicates lower infectivity and some immune response to the virus.

questions.text: Parvo B19 virus has tropism for-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Key Clinical Implications: Aplastic crisis in patients with chronic hemolytic anemias (e.g., sickle cell disease, thalassemia).
  • • Fifth disease (erythema infectiosum) in children — presents with "slapped cheek" rash.
  • • Hydrops fetalis in infected pregnant women (due to fetal anemia).
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Macrophages, C. T cells, D. B cells: These are not the primary target cells of Parvovirus B19. Other viruses like EBV (B cells) or HIV (T cells, macrophages) have tropism for these.

questions.text: Shingles is caused due to
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • After primary infection (chickenpox), the virus remains dormant in dorsal root ganglia and can reactivate later in life, causing the characteristic painful, unilateral vesicular rash along a dermatome.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Herpes simplex virus: Causes oral and genital herpes, but not shingles.
  • • C. Smallpox virus: Eradicated; causes generalized pustular rash, not shingles.
  • • D. HPV (Human Papillomavirus): Causes warts, not shingles.

questions.text: Sabin Feldman dye test for
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • It is considered the gold standard test for toxoplasmosis.
  • • The test works by mixing live Toxoplasma tachyzoites with patient serum and dye; if antibodies are present, the tachyzoites lose their ability to take up the dye (they remain colorless).
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Hydatid cyst and D. Echinococcus: Related to echinococcosis, diagnosed by imaging and other serologic tests, not the Sabin-Feldman test.
  • • C. Ancylostoma: A hookworm, diagnosed by stool examination, not by dye test.

questions.text: Urea breath test is done for
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • H. pylori produces the enzyme urease, which breaks down urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide.
  • • In this test, the patient ingests urea labeled with a carbon isotope (^13C or ^14C), and if H. pylori is present, labeled CO? is detected in the breath.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Campylobacter: A bacterial cause of gastroenteritis, diagnosed by stool culture, not urea breath test.
  • • B. Haemophilus: Causes respiratory infections; no urea breath test.
  • • C. Histoplasma: A fungal infection, diagnosed by culture or antigen detection.

questions.text: A person presented with multiple draining sinus having Sulphur granules at mandible. Probable organism is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Multiple draining sinuses especially around the mandible (known as lumpy jaw).
  • • Presence of “sulfur granules” in pus or discharge — yellowish granules composed of bacterial colonies.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Staphylococcus: Can cause abscesses but not sulfur granules or chronic draining sinuses.
  • • C. Streptococcus: Typically causes acute infections without sulfur granules.
  • • D. Listeria: Causes systemic infections, especially in neonates and immunocompromised, but not draining sinuses or sulfur granules.

questions.text: Pasteurization of milk is done at-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • There is also a High-Temperature Short-Time (HTST) method: 72°C for 15 seconds (not 20 minutes).
  • • Option A (72°C for 20 minutes) is incorrect for pasteurization; it's closer to HTST but with a too-long time.
  • • Option C (100°C for 20 minutes) corresponds to boiling or sterilization, not pasteurization.
  • • Option D (40°C for 60 minutes) is too low to kill pathogens.

questions.text: A patient from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9g/dl, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Thrombocytopenia (platelet count of 20,000/mm³) and prolonged bleeding time with a normal clotting time point to platelet dysfunction and vascular fragility typical of dengue hemorrhagic manifestations.
  • • The normal WBC count and anemia (Hb 9 g/dL) also fit the picture.
  • • Other infections like malaria or typhoid usually don’t cause such a prominent petechial rash or this pattern of bleeding abnormalities.
  • • Scrub typhus may cause rash but typically includes other symptoms and different lab findings.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis?

options.label: B
options.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

options.label: C
options.text: Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.correct_answer: B. Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • On a wet saline mount, it shows a characteristic twitching or jerky motility due to its flagella.
  • • It can be cultured in special media, so option A is incorrect.
  • • It does not form cysts; only the trophozoite form is seen in vaginal secretions, so option C is incorrect.
  • • It is definitely an STI, so option D is incorrect.

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Microscopy from the biopsy edge showing organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast is characteristic of Leishmania species.
  • • Leishmania tropica is the common species causing cutaneous leishmaniasis in India, including Rajasthan.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Babesia: Causes a malaria-like illness; no skin ulcers.
  • • C. Trypanosoma: Causes sleeping sickness or Chagas disease; no cutaneous ulcers typical in India.
  • • D. Histoplasma: A fungal infection causing pulmonary or disseminated disease; no kinetoplast.

questions.text: A child presents with a fever and a rash. Urine examination showed cells with owl’s eye appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • CMV can cause a variety of clinical presentations including fever and rash, especially in immunocompromised individuals or congenital infections.
  • • Detection of these inclusions in urine epithelial cells supports the diagnosis of CMV infection.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Epstein-Barr virus: Causes infectious mononucleosis; no owl’s eye inclusions.
  • • C. Herpes simplex virus: Causes vesicular lesions; different inclusion bodies.
  • • D. Toxoplasma gondii: A protozoan, no owl’s eye nuclear inclusions.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Chronic infection causes inflammation and epithelial hyperplasia of the bile ducts.
  • • This chronic irritation is strongly associated with an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer), especially in endemic areas like East Asia.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Cervical cancer: Mainly linked to HPV infection.
  • • C. Gastric carcinoma: Associated with Helicobacter pylori infection.
  • • D. Bladder carcinoma: Linked to Schistosoma haematobium infection, not Clonorchis.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He had a history of contact with multiple sexual partners. He was diagnosed with HIV positive 6 months back and is poorly adherent to his medications. The fungal culture of sputum was negative. On Gomori methamine silver staining, the cells showed darkly stained crescent shaped cysts. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Persistent cough, weight loss, and a negative fungal culture fit the picture of Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP).
  • • On Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) staining, Pneumocystis jirovecii appears as darkly stained, crescent or “cup-shaped” cysts.
  • • It cannot be cultured by routine fungal culture methods, explaining the negative culture.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis: Causes paracoccidioidomycosis, usually in South America.
  • • B. Histoplasma capsulatum: Shows small intracellular yeasts, not crescent-shaped cysts.
  • • C. Coccidioides immitis: Produces large spherules containing endospores, not crescent-shaped cysts.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory test is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea?

options.label: A
options.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.correct_answer: A. Antigen detection in the stool sample
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The most common and reliable diagnostic test is detection of rotavirus antigen in stool samples, usually by ELISA or rapid immunochromatographic tests.
  • • Antigen detection in blood or antibody detection in serum is not routinely used for diagnosis.
  • • Light microscopy of stool cannot detect the virus because rotavirus particles are too small and require special methods.

questions.text: A boy presented with fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • This rapid diagnostic test (RDT) is widely used for quick diagnosis of falciparum malaria.
  • • Other species like P. vivax, P. malariae, and P. ovale do not produce HRP-2, so they are not detected by this antigen.

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache and rigidity. CSF analysis showed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism?

options.label: B
options.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar

options.label: C
options.text: Exhibits satellitism around Staph aureus colonies

options.label: D
options.text: It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar

questions.correct_answer: C. Exhibits satellitism around Staph aureus colonies
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Haemophilus influenzae requires X (hemin) and V (NAD) factors for growth, which it cannot produce itself.
  • • On blood agar, it shows satellitism — it grows around colonies of Staphylococcus aureus, which produce the V factor, helping Haemophilus grow.
  • • It produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar is false; Haemophilus does not grow well on MacConkey agar.
  • • It is not bacitracin sensitive (this is characteristic of Streptococcus pyogenes).
  • • It does not exhibit alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar.

questions.text: A patient presented with high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

options.label: D
