options.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.correct_answer: C. CSF PCR for viral DNA
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • This test is highly sensitive and specific and is the gold standard.
  • • IgM in CSF is less reliable and not commonly used.
  • • Tzanck smear is useful for detecting multinucleated giant cells in skin lesions but not in CSF.
  • • CSF culture on chick embryo lines is outdated and not practical for HSV diagnosis.

questions.text: In a patient presented with a fever and a positive filarial antigen test, what is the next appropriate method of management?

options.label: C
options.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.correct_answer: C. Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • This helps in species identification (e.g., Wuchereria bancrofti) and in confirming active infection before starting treatment.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Bone marrow biopsy: Not indicated for filarial infection.
  • • B. DEC provocation test: Previously used to elicit microfilariae but largely outdated and unnecessary if antigen is already positive.
  • • D. Ultrasound of the scrotum: May show "filarial dance sign" in hydrocele, but it's supportive, not confirmatory.

questions.text: A man presents with a history of dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is the treatment of choice for gonorrhea due to rising resistance to penicillin and fluoroquinolones.
  • • The CDC currently recommends:
  • • Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM in a single dose for uncomplicated gonorrhea.
  • • Plus doxycycline (100 mg twice daily for 7 days) if chlamydial coinfection hasn’t been ruled out.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Erythromycin: Less effective and not recommended.
  • • B. Azithromycin: Was used in combination therapy, but resistance is increasing.
  • • D. Penicillin G: Resistance has made it ineffective for most N. gonorrhoeae strains.

questions.text: A child presented with perianal itching. Swab specimen Shown in the image. What is the diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The "scotch tape test" or perianal swab often reveals oval, flattened, asymmetrical eggs — a hallmark of Enterobius.
  • • These eggs are not typically found in stool and are best seen in the perianal region early in the morning.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Ascaris: Causes intestinal symptoms and respiratory signs (Löffler’s syndrome); eggs are found in stool, not on perianal skin.
  • • C. Trichiura (Whipworm): Can cause rectal prolapse and dysentery, but not perianal itching.
  • • D. Ancylostoma (Hookworm): Causes anemia, not perianal itching.

questions.text: A frequent traveller came with 4 days of remitting fever with abdominal pain and bradycardia. Best diagnostic test to confirm the pathogen is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Blood culture is the gold standard for diagnosing typhoid fever, especially in the first week of illness.
  • • It directly detects the bacteria in the bloodstream, offering both confirmation and antibiotic sensitivity.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Widal test: Serological test with limited sensitivity/specificity; often falsely positive or negative, especially in endemic areas or vaccinated individuals.
  • • C. Urine culture: Salmonella may be shed in urine but not reliably and not early.
  • • D. Stool culture: Useful later in the illness when the organism is shed in feces but not as sensitive as blood culture in early disease.

questions.text: An adult patient from military background admitted with rash, fever, altered sensorium with deficiency of Membrane attacking complex. What is the etiological agent?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Rash, fever, altered sensorium → classical features of meningococcal meningitis or septicemia
  • • Military background → crowded settings increase risk of outbreaks
  • • Deficiency of Membrane Attack Complex (MAC) → patients with complement C5–C9 deficiency are highly susceptible to Neisseria infections, especially Neisseria meningitidis
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Klebsiella pneumoniae: Causes pneumonia, especially in alcoholics/ICU, not associated with MAC deficiency.
  • • C. Haemophilus influenzae: Can cause meningitis but less linked to MAC deficiency.
  • • D. CMV: A viral infection, not typically presenting with rash and MAC complement association.

questions.text: A patient present with painful vesicles as shown in the image, What is the Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Caused by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) — most commonly HSV-2, though HSV-1 can also cause it.
  • • Lesions are:
  • • Painful
  • • Often multiple grouped vesicles on an erythematous base
  • • May ulcerate and crust
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Chancroid (Haemophilus ducreyi): Painful ulcer, but typically soft, with ragged edges and suppurative lymphadenopathy.
  • • B. Syphilis (Treponema pallidum): Painless chancre, clean base, firm edges.
  • • D. Candidiasis: Usually causes itching, thick white discharge, and satellite lesions, not vesicular ulcers.

questions.text: Patient admitted with bloody diarrhoea after consumption of oysters. Organism exhibits Kanagawa phenomenon. Choose the correct organism
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • It causes acute gastroenteritis, often with bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and sometimes nausea or vomiting.
  • • Kanagawa Phenomenon: This refers to beta-hemolysis on a special medium containing high salt and human red blood cells.
  • • It is a virulence marker — Kanagawa-positive strains are more likely to be pathogenic and cause severe diarrhea.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Staphylococcus aureus: Causes food poisoning with rapid-onset vomiting; not linked to oysters or bloody diarrhea.
  • • C. Campylobacter jejuni: Causes bloody diarrhea but not linked to Kanagawa phenomenon or seafood specifically.
  • • D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, not acute gastroenteritis from oysters.

questions.text: Desert rheumatism caused by
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • It typically occurs in endemic areas like the southwestern United States (e.g., Arizona, California), especially in desert regions.
  • • Features of Desert Rheumatism (Coccidioidomycosis): Fever
  • • Arthralgia (joint pain)
  • • Erythema nodosum (painful red nodules, usually on the shins)
  • • Cough or mild respiratory symptoms
  • • This syndrome reflects the body’s immune response rather than direct fungal invasion.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis: Causes paracoccidioidomycosis, common in South America (not associated with desert climates).
  • • B. Candida albicans: Causes mucocutaneous or systemic candidiasis, not desert rheumatism.
  • • C. Cryptococcus neoformans: Primarily causes meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, not linked to desert regions.

questions.text: Broad base budding yeasts seen in
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The organism appears as:
  • • Thick-walled yeast
  • • Broad-based buds
  • • Size: 8–15 µm
  • • This morphological feature is diagnostic and helps differentiate it from other fungal infections.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Histoplasmosis (Histoplasma capsulatum): Shows intracellular small oval yeasts, often within macrophages.
  • • C. Candidiasis (Candida spp.): Shows budding yeasts with pseudohyphae, not broad-based buds.
  • • D. Coccidioidomycosis (Coccidioides immitis): Shows spherules with endospores, not budding yeasts.

questions.text: A female patient admitted with UTI Coagulase negative, novobiocin resistant Staphylococcus, >104 grown in culture. It indicates
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Urinary tract infection symptoms
  • • Significant colony count (>10? CFU/mL) on culture
  • • Growth of a coagulase-negative Staphylococcus that is novobiocin resistant
  • • These findings point toward Staphylococcus saprophyticus, a common cause of UTI in young sexually active females.
  • • Key Features of Staphylococcus saprophyticus: Gram-positive, coagulase-negative
  • • Novobiocin resistant (helps distinguish it from Staph epidermidis, which is novobiocin sensitive)
  • • Second most common cause of community-acquired UTI after E. coli in young women
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Commensal: Although coagulase-negative staph can be commensals, S. saprophyticus in significant quantity from a symptomatic patient is pathogenic.
  • • C. Contamination: High colony count and clinical symptoms rule this out.
  • • D. Collect 3 consecutive samples: This is more relevant for blood cultures in bacteremia workup, not necessary for UTI diagnosis with clear findings.

questions.text: A 40 year old farmer came with Fever, Calf tenderness, Conjunctival suffusion, Retroorbital pain and Hypokalaemia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Fever
  • • Calf tenderness (classic for leptospirosis)
  • • Conjunctival suffusion (redness of the conjunctiva without pus)
  • • Retroorbital pain
  • • Hypokalemia
  • • These are typical signs of Leptospirosis, a zoonotic infection commonly seen in farmers exposed to water contaminated with urine of infected animals.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Malaria: Fever and chills common, but calf tenderness and conjunctival suffusion are not typical.
  • • B. Dengue: Retroorbital pain is common, but calf tenderness and conjunctival suffusion are not characteristic; dengue usually causes thrombocytopenia, not hypokalemia.
  • • D. Influenza: Presents with fever and body aches but lacks calf tenderness and conjunctival suffusion.

questions.text: A south Asian fruit farmer admitted with fever, breathlessness and encephalitis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus transmitted from fruit bats or contaminated fruit.
  • • Common in South and Southeast Asia, especially among people exposed to fruit bats or pig farms.
  • • Presents with:
  • • Acute febrile illness
  • • Respiratory symptoms (breathlessness)
  • • Encephalitis (altered sensorium, seizures)
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Ebola: Causes hemorrhagic fever, mostly in Africa.
  • • B. Zika: Mostly causes mild illness, rash, conjunctivitis, and birth defects, but not encephalitis or breathlessness typically.
  • • C. Malaria: Can cause encephalopathy but breathlessness and association with fruit farming less likely.

questions.text: A child admitted with Chorioretinitis, Hydrocephalus, Intracranial calcifications - what is the diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Chorioretinitis (inflammation of the retina and choroid)
  • • Hydrocephalus
  • • Intracranial calcifications (typically diffuse or scattered)
  • • This triad strongly suggests congenital toxoplasmosis, caused by Toxoplasma gondii infection during pregnancy.
  • • Why other options are less likely: A. Rubella: Causes cataracts, deafness, and PDA but not typically intracranial calcifications or hydrocephalus.
  • • B. CMV: Also causes intracranial calcifications but they are typically periventricular; hydrocephalus is less common.
  • • D. Zika: Associated with microcephaly and brain calcifications but not the full triad above.

questions.text: A sickle cell patient developed aplastic crisis following a viral infection. Choose the correct agent
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The virus infects and destroys erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, causing a sudden cessation of red blood cell production.
  • • This leads to a rapid drop in hemoglobin and can precipitate an aplastic crisis.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. EBV: Causes infectious mononucleosis but not aplastic crisis in sickle cell patients.
  • • C. HBV: Causes hepatitis; no direct link with aplastic crisis.
  • • D. CMV: Can cause marrow suppression but Parvovirus B19 is the classic agent for aplastic crisis in sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed EHEC 0157:H7 infection. Here H indicates
PLHIV-foul smelling stool. On microscopy no cyst / ova present. A 200micrometer larva present. What is the pathogen?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Strongyloides is a nematode that releases larvae (not ova) in stool, which is unique among intestinal parasites.
  • • It can cause severe disseminated infection in immunocompromised patients (like HIV).
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. Ascaris lumbricoides: Eggs (ova) are usually seen in stool, not larvae.
  • • C. Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm): Also ova in stool, not larvae.
  • • D. Schistosoma mansoni: Eggs are seen in stool; it’s a blood fluke, not a nematode.

questions.text: 2-year-old child came with watery diarrhoea. EM image shown here. Choose the correct pathogen
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Rotavirus is the most common cause of severe watery diarrhea in young children worldwide.
  • • On EM, it appears as a wheel-shaped virus (hence the name "rota" meaning wheel).
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Norwalk virus (Norovirus): Causes gastroenteritis but mostly in older children and adults; EM appearance is different.
  • • B. Adenovirus: Can cause diarrhea but less commonly in this age group and different morphology.
  • • C. ECHO virus: An enterovirus, causes aseptic meningitis and other illnesses, not typically severe watery diarrhea in toddlers.

questions.text: A women came with chronic history of fever, lower limb swelling. Microfilaria image shown here. Choose the correct pathogen
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Chronic fever
  • • Lower limb swelling (likely lymphedema or elephantiasis)
  • • Microfilaria seen on microscopy
  • • …is classic for lymphatic filariasis caused by Wuchereria bancrofti.
  • • Key identifying features of W. bancrofti microfilaria: Sheathed microfilaria
  • • Nuclei do not extend to the tip of the tail (important to differentiate from Brugia species)
  • • Commonly found in night blood samples
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Brugia malayi: Also causes lymphatic filariasis, but the terminal nuclei are distinctively separated.
  • • B. Mansonella spp.: Causes skin and subcutaneous infections, not typically associated with lower limb swelling.
  • • D. Loa loa: Causes Calabar swellings and is found in subcutaneous tissues, not lymphatics.

questions.text: An adult man came with dysuria, discharge from urethra with h/o unprotected sex. Gram stain image shown here, Best medium for this organism is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Dysuria
  • • Urethral discharge
  • • History of unprotected sexual intercourse
  • • Gram stain likely shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci → classic for Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • • Best medium for Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Thayer Martin agar: A selective medium that contains antibiotics (vancomycin, colistin, nystatin, and trimethoprim) to suppress the growth of contaminants and support only Neisseria species.
  • • Why other options are incorrect: B. MacConkey agar: For gram-negative enteric bacilli; Neisseria doesn’t grow well on it.
  • • C. Chocolate agar: Supports Neisseria but not selective – overgrowth by other flora possible.
  • • D. TCBS agar: Used for Vibrio species.

questions.text: Young boy used wash his contact lenses in tap water / Unhygienic lens fluid. Developed keratitis. Microscopy revealed organism with spikes. Choose the correct one
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Key Features of Acanthamoeba: Free-living amoeba found in tap water, soil, and lens solution.
  • • Causes severe keratitis in contact lens users.
  • • Microscopy may show double-walled cysts with spiny projections ("thorn-like" spikes).
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Balantidium: Causes colitis, not keratitis.
  • • B. Pseudomonas: Can cause keratitis, especially in contact lens users, but does not appear spiked under microscopy.
  • • D. Staph aureus: Can cause eye infections but is gram-positive cocci, not spiked organisms on microscopy.

questions.text: An adult man came with a clinical condition shown in the image. Gram negative diplococci found in Gram stain. What is the treatment?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Urethral discharge
  • • Gram stain showing gram-negative diplococci This is classic for Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection.
  • • Treatment of choice: Cefixime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is effective against N. gonorrhoeae.
  • • Alternatively, Ceftriaxone (IM) is the most widely recommended treatment in guidelines, but Cefixime (oral) is used when injection is not feasible.
  • • Why others are incorrect: A. Azithromycin: Previously used in combination for gonorrhea + chlamydia, but increasing resistance has limited its use.
  • • B. Penicillin: Not preferred due to widespread resistance in N. gonorrhoeae.
  • • D. Doxycycline: Used to treat chlamydia, not effective for gonorrhea alone.
  • • Current CDC recommendation (2024):
  • • Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM single dose is preferred.
  • • Doxycycline may be added if chlamydial co-infection is not ruled out.

questions.text: Infection in CVC found in a patient in ICU. Gram positive ovoid budding organism seen in microscopy. What is the organism?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Key Points: Candida is a yeast (fungus), appearing as gram-positive, ovoid, budding cells under the microscope.
  • • CVCs are a major risk factor for catheter-associated candidemia, especially in ICU settings with broad-spectrum antibiotic use or immunosuppression.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Staph epidermidis: Gram-positive cocci; common in catheter infections but appears in clusters (not budding yeast).
  • • C. E. coli: Gram-negative bacilli; not ovoid or budding.
  • • D. Staph aureus: Gram-positive cocci in clusters, not budding organisms.
  • • Summary: Budding yeast cells → Candida
  • • Common in ICU/CVC patients
  • • Confirmed by culture and may require antifungal therapy (e.g., echinocandins or fluconazole, depending on susceptibility).

questions.text: A farmer admitted with subcutaneous wound with discharge on his foot. Microscopy of white granule shows gram positive filamentous rods. What is the organism?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Key Identifiers: Nocardia:
  • • Gram-positive, filamentous, partially acid-fast.
  • • Found in soil – hence higher risk in farmers and gardeners.
  • • Causes cutaneous nocardiosis or mycetoma (when presenting with draining sinuses and granules).
  • • White granules in discharge = suggestive of mycetoma.
  • • Why the others are incorrect: A. Staphylococcus aureus:
  • • Gram-positive cocci, not filamentous.
  • • Can cause soft tissue infections, but no granules.
  • • B. Histoplasma:
  • • A fungus, usually causes pulmonary or systemic infections, not draining subcutaneous lesions with granules.
  • • D. Sporothrix schenckii:
  • • Causes sporotrichosis, often from rose thorns.
  • • Appears as cigar-shaped yeast in tissue, not filamentous gram-positive rods.

questions.text: Function of IL8
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • IL-8 (Interleukin-8) is a chemokine primarily involved in the chemotaxis of neutrophils. It is secreted by macrophages, endothelial cells, and other cells in response to pro-inflammatory stimuli such as IL-1 and TNF-α. IL-8 acts by binding to CXCR1 and CXCR2 receptors on neutrophils, guiding them toward sites of infection or tissue injury. This recruitment of neutrophils is crucial for initiating the innate immune response, allowing for phagocytosis of pathogens and subsequent inflammation. IL-8 does not affect lymphocytes or fever mechanisms directly but plays a central role in early immune defense through neutrophil activation and migration.
  • • Option B: Lymphocyte proliferation – Incorrect. This is primarily the function of IL-2, which is produced by activated T cells. IL-2 promotes the growth, proliferation, and differentiation of T cells, B cells, NK cells, and monocytes.
  • • Option C: TH1 activation – Incorrect. IL-12 is the major cytokine involved in the differentiation of naïve T cells into TH1 cells. IL-8 has no direct role in T helper cell subset differentiation.
  • • Option D: Fever – Incorrect. Fever is mainly induced by IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-α, which act on the hypothalamus to raise the body temperature. IL-8 is not pyrogenic and does not contribute to the febrile response.

questions.text: Patient from Bihar admitted with splenomegaly and features of leishmaniasis. What is the vector?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The vector for leishmaniasis in India, including endemic areas like Bihar, is the Phlebotomus sandfly, specifically Phlebotomus argentipes. These sandflies transmit Leishmania donovani, the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), when they bite humans and introduce the promastigote form of the parasite into the bloodstream. The disease is characterized by prolonged fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly (especially splenomegaly), and pancytopenia. Phlebotomus sandflies breed in moist soil and are active in dusk and dawn, making vector control an important aspect of disease prevention.
  • • Option B: Rat flea – Incorrect. Rat fleas, particularly Xenopsylla cheopis, are vectors of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, not leishmaniasis.
  • • Option C: Black fly – Incorrect. Black flies (Simulium species) transmit Onchocerca volvulus, the causative agent of onchocerciasis (river blindness), not leishmaniasis.
  • • Option D: Chrysops fly – Incorrect. The Chrysops fly, or deer fly, is the vector for Loa loa, the filarial worm responsible for loiasis, not leishmaniasis.

questions.text: Best PCR for identifying a syndrome/ Multiple causative agents is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Multiplex PCR is the best type of PCR for identifying a syndrome with multiple causative agents. This method allows the simultaneous amplification of multiple targets in a single PCR reaction by using more than one pair of primers. It is particularly useful in syndromic diagnosis (e.g., respiratory infections, gastroenteritis, meningitis) where a range of pathogens—viruses, bacteria, or parasites—can cause similar symptoms. By detecting several pathogens at once, it reduces time, cost, and sample requirement, making it a preferred tool in clinical diagnostics for syndromic panels.
  • • Option A: RT PCR – Incorrect. Reverse transcription PCR is used when the target is RNA, such as in RNA viruses (e.g., SARS-CoV-2, Influenza). While sensitive and quantitative, it's not designed specifically to detect multiple pathogens at once unless multiplexed, which would still fall under multiplex RT-PCR.
  • • Option C: Nested PCR – Incorrect. Nested PCR is a highly sensitive technique used to reduce non-specific binding in products from conventional PCR. It involves two sets of primers and two successive PCR reactions. It is excellent for detecting low levels of DNA, but not ideal for detecting multiple agents simultaneously.
  • • Option D: Conventional PCR – Incorrect. This is the standard form of PCR targeting one gene or organism at a time. While useful, it is not efficient for detecting multiple pathogens and lacks the high-throughput nature required for syndromic diagnosis.
